This structured network of powers, hierarchies, and values puts forward some models of masculinity and femininity that are universal and opposed to each other.

clueweb22-en0008-43-11390.point_content: Gender inequalities persist because people use gender as taken-for-granted common sense to manage their relationships with others, influenced by gender stereotypes.
spans: My research shows that the answers lie, above all, in how people think about gender as they relate to one another.
Day by day people use gender as taken-for-granted common sense to manage their relationships with others.
Interpersonal negotiations are constantly influenced by gender stereotypes

clueweb22-en0008-43-11390.point_content: Widely shared gender stereotypes act as a cultural frame that shapes interactions and perpetuates gender inequalities in various spheres.
spans: Research shows that widely shared gender stereotypes act as a “common knowledge” cultural frame that people use to begin the process of relating to one another and coordinating their interaction.

Social scientists and other observers have amassed lots of evidence showing that stereotypes and assumptions about men and women shape everyday personal interactions and shape gender inequalities in jobs, wages, authority, and family responsibilities.

clueweb22-en0008-43-11390.point_content: Traditional gender beliefs persist and influence new social and economic arrangements due to cultural lag and reliance on convenient cultural frames in uncertain situations.
spans: “common knowledge” gender stereotypes change more slowly than do material arrangements between men and women, even though social beliefs do eventually respond to material changes.
As a result of this cultural lag, people confront new, uncertain circumstances with traditional gender beliefs

Ironically, both the uncertainty and the personal closeness of such innovative settings increase the likelihood that participants will draw on the convenient cultural frames to organize new ways of doing things.

clueweb22-en0008-43-11390.point_content: Gender inequality is difficult to overcome because everyday gender assumptions shape ongoing social relationships in all spheres, requiring change in how people think as well as laws and policies.
spans: Once we understand how powerful everyday gender assumptions can be in shaping ongoing social relationships in all spheres, we better understand why gender inequalities are so difficult to overcome.
My research also suggests that the fight for gender equality will have to be waged at the level of how people think, even as laws and institutional policies open new doors.

clueweb22-en0015-01-10772.point_content: Sherry Ortner argues that women are second class citizens in every society because women are associated with nature and biology, particularly reproduction, which is seen as uncontrollable, while men are associated with culture, which controls nature.
spans: Sherry Ortner argues that women are second class citizens in every society.

Ortner's argument is that through shared experiences women in all societies have become associated with aspects of nature and biology that aren't controlled while men became associated with aspects of culture, which controls nature.

clueweb22-en0015-01-10772.point_content: The biological reality of women's reproductive role makes them vulnerable and bound to the homestead, limiting their participation in dangerous activities and public power roles, while men engage in hunting, war, politics, and cultural achievements.
spans: Basically, there is the biological reality that females give birth. This is dangerous, takes a ton of resources, and then the woman is burdened with caring for the child until it is old enough to out on its own.
While pregnant and while breastfeeding she is not only vulnerable but the baby is vulnerable.
This means she needs to be protected and therefore is less likely to go out hunting or engaging in other dangerous activities.

Men, then, were free to not only hunt but engage in war, negotiate with nearby communities, go exploring, develop dangerous technologies like metal smithing, politics, and other cultural achievements.

clueweb22-en0015-01-10772.point_content: Control of female sexuality and virginity is linked to property and inheritance, leading to patrilineal societies where women's sexuality is controlled to ensure legitimate heirs, reinforcing gender inequality.
spans: Ortner also argues that control of sexuality for women plays into this development of society.
She argues that the concern over female virginity comes from the development of property and inheritance.
Because of aforementioned arguments, she says that men are the ones in power so societies become patrilineal.
Prior to the invention of DNA testing, the only way to know for sure who was the father was to control the sexuality of the mother.
So women get locked away, limited in their abilities to enter the public sphere, and socially controlled in a variety of ways.

clueweb22-en0015-01-10772.point_content: Gender inequality increased with the transition from hunter-gathering to sedentary farming life, where inheritance and accumulation of wealth became important, reducing women's reproductive and economic freedom.
spans: I think it is interesting to note that there is a severe upswing in gender inequality with a transition from hunter-gathering to sedentary life.
A number of the issues firedrops mentions are really only prevalent among sedentary peoples.

In summary, while it could maybe be argued that men have a little more control over women among hunter-gatherers, it's proportionally much smaller because women have more reproductive and economic freedom.
TL;DR: The origin of farming is heavily correlated to the roots of inequality.

clueweb22-en0015-01-10772.point_content: Women had to stay at home to feed and care for children due to their ability to breastfeed, while men could leave for hunting, trading, and fighting, which eventually led to men gaining political power.
spans: All females share one common trait: their mammory glands worked.
Men's boobs don't work. They do not produce milk and therefore cannot provide any nourishment for the children.
This means that women across the board were the ones that had to stay at home and feed the children with the exception of being able to leave for a small amount of time to gather flora and water.
Men had to do these jobs because (due, again, to their lack of working mammory glands) they could leave and not come back for an extended amount of time.
These responsibilities eventually led to politics. Trading and war agreements went to those who hunted and fought.
